Ireland Politics Scotland Scotland Politics Wales Wales Politics Africa Asia China India Australia Europe Latin America Middle East In Pictures BBC InDepth BBC Verify Sport Business Executive Lounge Technology of Business Future of Business Innovation Technology Science & Health Artificial Intelligence AI v the Mind Culture Film & TV Music Art & Design Style Books Entertainment News Arts Arts in Motion Travel Destinations Africa Antarctica Asia Australia and Pacific Caribbean & Bermuda Central America Europe Middle East North America South America World’s Table Culture & Experiences Adventures The SpeciaList Earth Natural Wonders Weather & Science Climate Solutions Sustainable Business Green Living Audio Podcast Categories Radio Audio FAQs Video BBC Maestro Live Live News Live Sport Home News Sport Business Innovation Culture Arts Travel Earth Audio Video Live Weather Newsletters Arts This Indigenous winter scene is not what it seems Satirical artist Wendy Red Star is debunking myths and upending cliches about First Nation and Native people. Now two exhibitions are featuring her work. The 'It Girl' style wars of Renaissance Italy During a turbulent period of Italian history, some noblewomen used flamboyant, luxurious looks to gain soft power. Five hundred years later, they continue to influence designers. Why Shakespeare's wife and son remain a mystery Oscar-tipped new film Hamnet imagines the home life of William and Agnes Shakespeare – and the "soul-crushing" loss of their child. It's a powerful story that fills in many blanks. Feature The truth about Tudor England's 'most hated woman' Was 16th-Century aristocrat Jane Boleyn a treacherous, "sex-mad" spy – or was she a convenient scapegoat? A new book explores her story. See more Arts in Motion In a pioneering new collaboration, the BBC – in partnership with Rolex – celebrates excellence in arts and culture. See more Around the world Is this 1768 painting the real birth of modern art? While many argue that "modern art" began in the 1800s, could it actually have started with Joseph Wright of Derby's An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump, nearly a century before? What ancient women really thought about sex Author Daisy Dunn's book, The Missing Thread, tells the history of the ancient world through women. The 80s Christmas TV horror that terrified Britain First airing on Christmas Eve 1989, the original TV adaptation of Susan Hill's creepy novel The Woman in Black contains what some consider one of the greatest scares in screen history. Watch Why dancing is key to our humanity What can our long love affair with dance teach us about ourselves? Humanity The spectacular art museum under the sea Can art and conservation work hand in hand to save our oceans? Culture Exploring Japan's ancient tradition of lacquerware Find out how Japan's renowned Wajima-nuri lacquerware is crafted through more than 100 intricate steps. Culture & Experiences Inside the largest private gothic palace in Venice Palazzo Fortuny was the home of Mariano Fortuny y Madrazo and Henriette Negrin, two artists, fashion designers and inventors who gave the world more than 100 patents. Travel A look back at operatic legend Maria Callas' life Greek-American soprano Maria Callas, hailed as one of the greatest singers in operatic history, remains an icon for young performers today. Opera Art history The centuries-old origins of the witch's hat As Wicked: For Good is released, what are the historic meanings of conical headwear, and how has it evolved – from its ancient origins to the empowered Elphaba? How a Klimt became the most expensive modern artwork The clues hidden in a true-crime masterpiece Why art robberies exploded in the 20th Century How Lee Miller's photos captured the horror of WW2 Photography 'The male nude is still a taboo' Can the male body be eroticised like women’s? London-based photographer Yushi Li explores the subject. See more Classical music The music that keeps animals calm You can find many different playlists for dogs and cats online. However, not all styles of music are effective. How the Psycho music score changed film forever Alfred Hitchcock's grisly horror might not have become a classic without composer Bernard Herrmann's disturbing score. Does Notre-Dame still sound the same? Performers and visitors to the famous gothic cathedral in the midst of the River Seine may find some subtle differences to the way sound bounces around its walls. How music saved a cellist's life in Auschwitz After being sent to the Nazi death camp in 1943, Anita Lasker survived by playing in its women's orchestra. In 1996, she spoke to the BBC about her ordeal. The most misunderstood Oscar winner ever Miloš Forman's best picture-winning Amadeus is often accused of historical inaccuracies – but the film's critics could be missing the point. How opera is aiming for net zero Many opera companies are working towards full sustainability, and Glyndebourne is among those aiming to be a force for good. More stories 29 mins ago Five miracles of Christ painting sold for £5.7m The 15th-Century painting exceeds Sotheby's valuation of between £2.5m and £3.5m. 29 mins ago 37 mins ago Eight paint colours that can transform your home As Pantone announces its colour of 2026, here's more on the reasoning behind the choice – and what other trending shades can help you achieve greater domestic bliss. 37 mins ago 1 hr ago Barnsley to host art festival's 10th edition AND Festival will take place between 25 and  27 September 2026 1 hr ago 1 hr ago Play a 'love letter' to city's migrants The story is told through the eyes of two Pakistani immigrants arriving in Oxford in 1999. 1 hr ago 6 hrs ago Theatre supporters fight on despite demolition vote The trust which hoped to run Cannock's Prince of Wales Theatre says it saw over 70,000 visitors a year. 6 hrs ago 7 hrs ago Elizabethan portrait sells at auction for £3.2m Sotheby's says the 1562 picture of the fourth Duke of Norfolk set a record for an Elizabethan work. 7 hrs ago 7 hrs ago 'I can't wait to make my Northern Irish debut' - Opera star Tara Erraught The internationally acclaimed singer performs at Londonderry's St Columb's Hall on Thursday. 7 hrs ago 19 hrs ago Reopening of Raac-impacted Key Theatre delayed Landmark Theatres says the work in Peterborough is now due to be completed by next May. 19 hrs ago 24 hrs ago Teenager to fulfill dream dancing on Broadway Finn, 16, from Consett, is picked to fulfil a dream dancing on New York's Broadway at Christmas. 24 hrs ago ...
